newsitem.title: USA: Mich. needs more time to assess renaissance zones.
newsitem.headline: Mich. needs more time to assess renaissance zones.

text.p: Michigan will need more time to judge the success of tax-free renaissance zones intended to spur economic development in isolated areas of the state, Standard & Poor's said in its CreditWeek Municipal publication this week.
"Although several projects have been proposed and development interest has increased in the months since the program was established, more time is required to judge the plan's success," S&P said.

Michigan established the program earlier this year at 11 sites statewide, including Detroit, Flint, Grand Rapids, Saginaw and Lansing, S&P said. Properties and economic activity within the districts are exempt from state income, single business and property taxes, as well as local property, income and utility use taxes, S&P noted.

Detroit officials have estimated that the 1,345-acre zone would general 14,000 new jobs and the Michigan Jobs Commission has reported a large number of inquiries about relocations and expansions in the last few months, S&P said.

In Grand Rapids, an investment group has announced a planned $5 million factory-to-office and retail space renovation, S&P noted. A manufacturer currently leasing a building in the Grand Rapids rennaisance zones also plans to buy it and invest $10 million for renovations, S&P said.

"From a credit perspective, the impact on the municipalities that house these zones is unclear," S&P said. "Obviously, any development encouraged by the creation of the zones, which would not have occurred without zones themselves, would have a positive impact on the local economy.
"It is unclear, however, whether the costs of providing increased services within a municipality's developing sector will be completely offset by the generation of indirect revenues," S&P said.
Stabilizing influences within certain areas could have a positive influence on surrounding areas, resulting in some tax revenue increases over the longterm, S&P said.
Michigan Gov. John Engler announced last week that private firms had invested $66.85 million in 17 projects since the program started, creating 938 to 1,139 new jobs.
